prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To unambiguously identify a complex organic molecule, we need to detect as many molecular transitions as possible to avoid misidentification of chance interlopers. Therefore, if only going after a few (blended) bandheads at higher frequencies for detections, we may not be able to make an unambiguous detection.
The expected line intensities of pyrimidine doublets vary between 30 and 60 mJy/bm at 212 GHz (Fig 5(b)). To play safe, an expected line intensity of 40 mJy/bm was adopted for estimation. Using the 212-GHz pyrimidine doublets as our reference, we expect the pyrimidine lines in Band 7, e.g. at 342 or 348 GHz, will be about a factor of 3 weaker than that at 212 GHz, or with an intensity of about 15 mJy/bm, assuming an excitation temperature of 100 K (here we did not consider possible corrections of beam dilution as source sizes vary largely; Figs 3 & 5). However, pyrimidine bandheads become more compact, hence with a more significant blending effect, toward higher frequencies, bandhead lines with intensities stronger than 15 mJy/bm are expected. Given a 30% increase of line intensity due to spectral compactness, we would find that an rms of 5 mJy/bm in Band 7 will be a reasonable choice which would ensure an S/N ratio of ~4 (or greater).
As demonstrated in the ALMA 212-GHz spectrum (Fig. 5(b)), although we did detect two non-band pyrimidine lines outside the 212-GHz bandhead, we encountered a problem in resolving the individual transitions within the 212-GHz bandhead into discernible (multi-)lines. The spectral resolution adopted for our 212-GHz Cycle-0 data is 876 kHz (or a channel spacing of 488 kHz and 0.69 km/s in velocity space). In Orion KL, the typical linewidth of a weak molecular line is around 2.0 to 2.5 km/s. Thus, to ensure detections of pyrimidine bandheads, individual lines within bandheads, and low-J doublet lines, a spectral resolution of 488 kHz is adopted for all Science Goals.
Because there are many non-bandhead pyrimidine transitions spread to a wider spectral distribution up to 500 MHz near its bandheads, a 1/2 FRACTION is selected for all BBs.
Based on our ALMA images (Fig. 5), we estimate the LAS to be ~4.0 with a typical source size of ~1.5.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Many complex organic molecules found in interstellar clouds are prebiotically important and have essential functions in terrestrial biochemistry. Pyrimidine, the building block of nucleic acid, is a key molecule for astrobiology, and was detected in meteorites and may be components of Halley's CHON dust. Although the formation of prebiotic molecules in extraterrestrial environment and their contribution to the origin of life remains unsettled, the connection between interstellar organic chemistry, meteoritic pyrimidines, and the emergence of life on early Earth would be strengthened with the discovery of pyrimidine. Our prior search using the JCMT and SMA in Orion KL suggests possible detections of pyrimidine bandheads at 212 and 342 GHz. A serendipitous search in Cycle 0 data discloses likely pyrimidine doublet-lines near the 212-GHz bandhead, though higher spectral resolution is needed for an unequivocal firm detection. The proposed observations will not only test the idea that grain-surface reactions lead to organic ring isomers, more importantly, a detection of pyrimidine will have fundamental implications for astrobiology, thus of the great interest of the general public.
